Scope and form:
Lectures and exercises.

Exercises include hands-on exercises (up to 30% of the total in class time), image analysis and journal club-type activity (not part of hands-on).

Hands-on exercises are comprised of:
- 2 rotating exercises about basic methods.
- one image analysis exercise.
- a mini-project in smaller groups on research-grade instruments including sample preparation, imaging, image analysis, interpretation of, e.g., imaging artifacts.
Type of assessment:
Oral examination and reports
Individual oral examination, lab journals and reports written in groups. The final grade is based on an overall assessment of lab journals, the project report and the oral exam. Submitting the lab journals and the project report is a prerequisite for attending the oral exam.

General course objectives:
General course objectives
The goal of the course is to equip DTU students (MSc and PhD students) with various backgrounds with the theoretical and practical skills to use light microscopy to its full capabilities in life science applications as demanded by the industry as well as many branches of research.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
describe basic optical principles like interference, diffraction, conjugate planes, aperture stops, and determine magnification, resolution, field of view, illumination optics, and choice of detector.
describe various contrast mechanisms, including bright-field/dark-field, phase contrast, and fluorescence.
explain basic operation of microscopes including bright-field/dark-field microscopy, fluorescence, and confocal microscopy.
explain operation of advanced techniques, including multi-photon excited fluorescence microscopy, total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy, and optical coherence tomography.
explain the working principles of three class of super-resolution microscopy based on the limitation of conventional microscopy.
evaluate and compare techniques including bright-field/dark-field microscopy, fluorescence microscopy, confocal microscopy and nonlinear microscopy (multi-photon).
assess scientific papers within the areas of the course, evaluate the presented choice of modalities, and propose alternative approaches.
illustrate adequate choice of microscope technique by analysing performance in terms of resolution, field-of-view, choice of detector, and signal-to-noise considerations.
choose and argue the applicability of a specific microscope technique to a given life science problem.
choose and apply methods for analysis of microscopy image data, including image segmentation, feature detection, point-spread function analysis, single-emitter localization, and particle-tracking.
design a microscopy experiment including choice of contrast mechanism, instrument, light sources, optical filters, staining, and detector.
Content: A strong focus on fluorescence microscopy techniques that may be applied in the life sciences.
Remarks: The course is suitable for and open to PhD students.
